LINKAGES, a new cooperative agreement, will scale up HIV prevention, care and treatment for key populations (KP) to reduce new HIV infections. LINKAGES will build on foundational work and emerging science to reach sex workers (SW), men who have sex with men (MSM) and transgender persons (TG) effectively. Malawian KP are disproportionately affected by HIV, yet face barriers to risk reduction and service utilization due to marginalization, discrimination and criminalization of behavior. Reaching them with comprehensive HIV services requires tailored approaches delivered by trusted networks of health providers and civil society organizations (CSO).
The results of the integrated biologic and behavioral survey and national size estimations underway will inform project design. Planned coverage will initially target five districts with high density of KP and expand over five years. The project will deliver HIV services based on global guidance, tailored to Malawi’s context. Peer-led activities will increase self- and community-efficacy to adopt healthy behaviors and access services addressing the continuum of care for HIV+ individuals. Clinical services or referrals will include STI, HTC, Family Planning, Treatment and Care. Structural interventions will address discrimination by service providers, and violence and harassment perpetuated by police and SW clients.
LINKAGES will advocate for increased national prioritization of targeted programs through guidelines development and health worker training to expand respectful health services. CSO capacity development will strengthen local ownership and sustainability.
